subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: Kent, You could provide updates using jnlp. http://java.sun.com/products/javawebstart/ http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/Programming/jnlp/
messageBody:
Kent,

You could provide updates using jnlp.
http://java.sun.com/products/javawebstart/
http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/Programming/jnlp/

Cheers,

Daniel

Le mardi 08 novembre 2005 à 11:58 -0800, Kent Beck a écrit :
> Elliotte,
>
> Thank you for your perspective. I understand that multiple releases would solve the problem of premature commitment to flexibility that later becomes an uncomfortable constraint. I was asking how to make multiple releases when our JAR file gets incorporated with third-party products. My first choice would be some kind of automatic update mechanism. If I understand your suggestion correctly, you are suggesting that I just don't worry about updating JUnit, as people who are interested in writing new Runners are motivated enough to go get the new release. I will give up on the update mechanism if necessary, but first I woulk like to know if anyone out there had experiences with a simple, reliable way to automatically update releases.
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>

> > Kent Beck wrote:
> > > Elliotte,
> > >
> > > Thank you for this perspective. You are absolutely right
> > that if we had frequent releases the optimal strategy would
> > be to conceal everything possible in the framework and open
> > it up "on demand". I don't see how to implement frequent
> > releases with JUnit, however, since the IDE vendors bake
> > JUnit into their offerings and we don't have any
> > infrastructure to push updates. Perhaps I am just fussing
> > about this, or there is a simple solution. I am open to suggestions.
> > >
> >
> > Most developers will not need to extend JUnit at all, no
> > matter how many
> > or which hooks you provide. If one does need an extra extension point
> > that you decide is a good idea, then you can add it and make
> > a release.
> > The developers who need it can fairly easily install it in
> > their IDE or
> > other framework. As long as you don't actively change the
> > published API
> > or remove any pieces of it, the IDE should continue to work. So I
> > wouldn't worry excessively about leaving something out.
> >
